text:
Liu Yuanqi was a pupil of Qian Gu (1508-78) who, in turn, was a direct disciple of Wen Zhengming (1470-1559), one of the four great masters of the Wu school. Not surprisingly, this painting accords well with sixteenth-century Suzhou literati values.
This large scroll, intended for a main hall, is one of Liu's earliest and most ambitious paintings. Since the majority of his output was on a small, intimate scale, this monumental scroll appears to have been his masterwork. A lone scholar is shown crossing a small bridge in the bottom foreground. He gazes up past a rustic retreat toward a pavilion situated high on a rocky promontory in front of a cascading waterfall. In spite of the densely patterned surface, the composition is clearly articulated and the brushwork generally relaxed and easy. The basic theme, pictorial structure, and dotted textures are all reminiscent of ink landscapes produced by Wen Zhengming.
title: Scholar in Landscape
